title: Multiline select starting column should be the position of the mouse at the start, not the first selector
body:
When you make a multiline selection after the end of a line then drag down to others, the starting column for each line isn't the position of the mouse at the start of the selection, but the column of the first selected line's last character, which makes selecting multiple ends of lines difficult for lines of differing length.

How it works in SublimeText 3:
https://gfycat.com/BrilliantBlankAmazonparrot

How it works in VS Code:
https://gfycat.com/LavishEllipticalKronosaurus

It would be awesome if it worked like Sublime's multiselect in this case, since that is my only real gripe with VSCode, after switching from Sublime.

title: [folding] Move line up/down should skip over folded regions or folded sections

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version:1.30.0-insider
- OS Version: windows 10

I think when code is in a folded region or section it should never unfold unless explicitly commanded, so if you are moving a line using move command, the line should skip over both folded regions and folded sections
Steps to Reproduce:

1. create a folded region using #region #endregion
2. fold some code section
3. move a line using alt+up/down over the folded region/section

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

title: Aligning Toggle Developer Tools  & Open Webview Developer Tools
body:
Issue Type: Bug This is very minor but... IMO it would be great to align the `Developer: Toggle Developer Tools` and `Developer: Open Webview Developer Tools` commands. I know they are technically accurate, since the former actually toggles, while the latter just opens. But I find that dichotomy an issue (albeit a very minor one). For example, I've seen confusion from a few devs trying to find the dev tools command (because they looked for open first), and then once they learn it is _Toggle_ rather than _Open_, they can't find the webview dev tools which is `Developer: Open Webview Developer Tools`. And I always find myself typing the wrong thing for what I'm looking for -- sometimes I type _toggle_ when I'm looking for the webview tools, and _open_ for the normal dev tools. And I'm sure your asking yourself why I don't just type `dev` to find them, but for something reason that has yet to stick in muscle memory 😉 VS Code version: Code - Insiders 1.30.0-insider (d3bb20c3fd1f23c369b80dca2ed25d54efd664e2, 2018-11-27T08:27:31.447Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.18290

title: Show actual description for commands in Extensions Contributions section

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
The `Description` section in the Extensions Contributions section for commands shows the command title instead of command description.

I would say 2 most important things for a user in this section is the command title and description. Command id, keyboard shortcuts, menu contexts are all secondary information.

No one needs the id, unless they want to customize the keyboard shortcut.
Most of the commands dont have a default keyboard shortcut, and so that column is mostly empty. 
Most of the commands arent part of any menu, and so the Menu Contexts column is also mostly empty.

A new user or a existing user new to an extension would like to know what the extension can do. Command title and description is what will help. And so, these 2 should get priority in the limited real estate of the Contributions section

Note that there is no place in VS Code where one can see the descriptions of the commands contributed by an extension.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16890566/49181411-27f00a80-f30c-11e8-8c6d-89c6841c3daa.png)


VS Code version: Code - Insiders 1.30.0-insider (d3bb20c3fd1f23c369b80dca2ed25d54efd664e2, 2018-11-27T08:27:31.447Z)
OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.17763


<!-- generated by issue reporter -->

title: vscode.debug API should provide the current thread/stack frame ids

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

body: Currently the `vscode.debug` API provides a way to send custom events to debug adapters. But it is missing one fairly important thing - there is no way to know what the current thread id / frame id is. So a debug adapter could maybe guess. But it feels like there should really be a way to query this.

Steps to Reproduce:

I can not run the usual vscode tasks over sftp even if they operate in the workspace root:

"options": {

(in .vscode/tasks.json)
and even if the cwd is not given.

I always get

```text
chdir(2) failed.: No such file or directory
The terminal process terminated with exit code: 1
```

Is this a known issue or does it work for others?

title: Better text for this type of warning
body:
Version: 1.29.1 (system setup)
Commit: bc24f98b5f70467bc689abf41cc5550ca637088e
Datum: 2018-11-15T19:13:36.375Z
Electron: 2.0.12
Chrome: 61.0.3163.100
Node.js: 8.9.3
V8: 6.1.534.41
Architektur: x64
Windows 10

I get today this message in the right bottom corner:
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/260343/49068136-411e8b80-f226-11e8-8231-602b90650b9f.png)

translated means:

> tomoki1207.pdf was reported as problematic and was therefore uninstalled

So first think was: I have no file "tomoki1207.pdf" open in my vscode, because this messsage look like for a normal pdf-file. So what is this strange message box? A pdf is "uninstalled"?

With searchmachine I found the explaination: https://github.com/tomoki1207/vscode-pdfviewer
Its means the **extension** "vscode-pdfviewer". So please write "Extension" at beginning of the warning and better use the name of extension and not the cryptic filename of extension.

More information about "problematic " with this extension would be nice.
Found answer here: https://github.com/tomoki1207/vscode-pdfviewer/issues/33

title: Add "TypeAlias" CompletionItemKind/SymbolKind
body:
"Type alias" is whenever an identifier is used to reference another type by a different name, aka "typedef" or "using alias" (see https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/type_alias ).

Applies to the following languages: C, C++, Objective-C, D, C#, Go, Rust, Swift, and probably other languages.

Our C/C++ workaround is to use the "Interface" icon with the text "(typedef)" or "(type alias)" appended.

For Visual Studio with C++ it shows:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19859882/48880491-917c9000-edc5-11e8-9b35-3e19842aaeb8.png)

title: Add more types to CompletionItemKind/SymbolKind
body:
This would allow our C/C++ extension to show a different icon. Also applies to Objective-C and D. Our workaround is to use the "Struct" icon with additional text "(union)" at the end of the symbol.

This is what Visual Studio shows:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19859882/48880516-b96bf380-edc5-11e8-8723-1d6266671b4e.png)

title: Allow text search provider to return results in relevance order, rather than sorting by path
body:
A search provider may want to return results in sorted order.

❓ How does a provider opt in to this scoring? Does return order matter or does it provide a score with each result?
❓ Are they scored by path or by individual match?

title: Let Extensions Change Line Height
body:
We would like the following extensibility features in VS Code (to match the same extensibility points already shipping in Visual Studio):

1.	The ability to change a line’s height.
2.	The ability to change a line’s caret height (independently of the line height).
3.	The ability to hide special coded text (such as inside a comment) on the line (or paint over it – like an adornment).
4.	The ability to intercept the mouse click/down/up/over events so we can interact with adornments as first class citizens.

Context: These changes would allow extension developers to create plugins that support editing and viewing of rich documents and source code inside VS Code. For example, developers could edit markdown files, seeing embedded images right inside the file, or developers could add LaTeX formulas to comments and see them rendered beautifully as math formulas in the code. This would also allow the CodeRush team to port over the [embedded images feature](https://community.devexpress.com/blogs/markmiller/archive/2018/09/11/holy-grail-embedded-images-inside-source-code.aspx) from CodeRush to VS Code as a free plugin.

![Sample Embedded Image in Code](https://community.devexpress.com/blogs/markmiller/embeddedJet_thumb_281AA4BF.png) 

**Update**: This change will help us port other CodeRush features to VS Code, including:

The **Debug Visualizer**, which shows the values of expressions under the expression, as you step through the code:

![Debug Visualizer](https://devexpress.gallerycdn.vsassets.io/extensions/devexpress/coderushforroslyn/18.2.9/1554483771582/234103/1/DebugVisualizer2.png)

**LaTeX Formulas** in Source Code Comments:
![LaTeX Formulas](https://community.devexpress.com/blogs/markmiller/Images/LaTeX/LatexFormulas.png)

Source Code Comments with **custom font sizes**:
![Tiny Comments](https://community.devexpress.com/blogs/markmiller/Images/TinyComments.png)

title: How to get Emmet to generate a custom JSX attribute without quotes

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
By default, when I expand an html tag with an attribute, the attribute's value gets surrounded by quotes.
I'm trying to remove the quotes generated by Emmet around the props.onClick value for custom attribute onClick.

My input (then TAB to expand):
`button[onClick={props.onClick}]`

Emmet's output:
`<button onClick="props.onClick"></button>`

Whereas, when I'm using React, I want to have to specify when I want the expanded version to have quotes. What I expect (props... WITHOUT quotes):

`<button onClick={props.onClick}></button>`

Wrapping it around double brackets doesn't work either. Is that possible with vscode.emmet?

title: Drag and drop - sort - properties of object/array and parameters of function
body:
For example:

When you want move par3 to two position:
`const fn = (par1, par2, par3)=> {};`
to
`const fn = (par1, par3, par2)=> {};`

Hold Ctrl. Hover over the function parameter.
The function parameter lights up and the cursor changes to "grabbing".
You grab the parameter and move it to the chosen location.
Commas set up automatically as you need.
You do not have to check the parameter, you do not have to manually change the commas.

The same method with shifting the object / array properties.

It's a small thing, and it seems to be very comfortable.

title: Portable mode: Presence of data folder prevents --user-data-dir command-line override

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
- VSCode Version: 1.29.1 bc24f98b5f70467bc689abf41cc5550ca637088e
- OS Version: Windows 10 (1709)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Have content of `VSCode-...-.zip` unpacked into say `C:\apps\VSCode`
2. Create `C:\apps\VSCode\data` folder ([docs](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/portable))
3. Invoke `C:\apps\VSCode\bin\code.cmd --user-data-dir C:\other-data-dir`
 (aside: no [command-line](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/command-line) argument apparently works on C:\apps\VSCode\Code.exe  (#57185))

Expected outcome:
`C:\other-data-dir` folder is created and populated with default profile (or used if existed already).

Actual outcome:
`C:\apps\VSCode\data\user-data` folder is created and populated, rendering command-line switch ineffective.

4. delete `C:\apps\VSCode\data` folder
5. Repeat step 3.

Actual outcome is now correct.

title: API should install extensions defined in extensionPack before running extension tests
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

I ran into #30165 because I was making use of settings contributed by another extension defined in extensionPack. This causes our CI tests to fail, because that extension isn't downloaded before the extension tests are run:

```
### VS Code Extension Test Run ###
Current working directory: ...
Downloading VS Code into ... from: https://vscode-update.azurewebsites.net/1.29.1/linux-x64/stable
Running extension tests: /home/travis/build/IBM-Blockchain/blockchain-vscode-extension/client/.vscode-test/stable/VSCode-linux-x64/code /home/travis/build/IBM-Blockchain/blockchain-vscode-extension/client/out/test --extensionDevelopmentPath=/home/travis/build/IBM-Blockchain/blockchain-vscode-extension/client --extensionTestsPath=/home/travis/build/IBM-Blockchain/blockchain-vscode-extension/client/out/test
```

Would it be possible to update the test script in the api to download the _other_ extensions defined in the extensionPack category so we won't have to work around this? 
(My work around was just to stub out the get and update function calls where we're making use of the other extension's settings. Not ideal but works)

title: Support updating multiple workspace configuration settings at once...

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
hey there :wave:

my extension manages a number of custom workspace configuration settings (established via the `contributes.configuration.properties` object in my `package.json` / manifest file). i monitor these settings using `workspace.onDidChangeConfiguration()` and take action when `event.affectsConfiguration()` signals that a relevant change has occurred.

i'd like to expose a command that a user can invoke to be walked through the process of updating _multiple_ configuration settings within their workspace. kind of like a set up wizard UX.

the problem i'm running into is that there does not appear to be a way to update _multiple_ configuration values at once. 

instead, i'm forced to update them like so:

```javascript
await config.update('foo', foo, ConfigurationTarget.Workspace);
await config.update('bar', bar, ConfigurationTarget.Workspace);
await config.update('baz', baz, ConfigurationTarget.Workspace);
```

which causes my `onDidChangeConfiguration()` to be called three times (once for each change). in this scenario, i want to emit _one_ change event once all three settings have been updated.

i can work-around the current behavior by simply debouncing my event handler or managing some global flag and exiting my event handler early based on whether or not it is set or even just editing the `.code-workspace` json file myself using node's `fs.writeFile`, etc. however, this doesn't prevent 3rd party listeners from running and / or is generally a bit clunky.

it would be great if there was support for something like this:

```javascript
await config.update('myExtension', { foo, bar, baz }, ConfigurationTarget.Workspace);
```

which would then update those three values but only emit one change event.

title: Docker-TypeScript with node:10-slim breaks sourcemaps mapping URL
Allow decorations to contain multiple lines of text
body:
Using [ThemableDecorationAttachmentRenderOptions#contentText](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/extensionAPI/vscode-api#ThemableDecorationAttachmentRenderOptions) it's possible to specify a string to be displayed at a specific position in the source code. However, newlines in this string are ignored.

This limitation makes some features hard to implement, e.g. for Scala 3 we've developed a vscode extension which contains a [worksheet mode](http://dotty.epfl.ch/docs/usage/worksheet-mode.html) that runs every line of code in the current buffer and displays the corresponding output on the right side of the screen. This is done using decorations, but when the output spans multiple lines we're forced to add new empty lines in the user code to properly display it, this is hacky and fragile.

Another usecase for newlines in decorations is displaying compiler-generated code: for example, a user might want to see what code a macro generates, and this code may span multiple lines.

title: Add differing numbers to multiline editing
body: Pretty much, I thought it might be nice to add the ability to put a character (such as $ for emmet) so that while you are editing multiple lines using the multicursor function you can input different numbers for each line instead of writing the lines all with the same number then modifying it later.
